title: 104_hr1084
content: The Act titled "Federal Employees Health Benefits Access Act" allows for the availability of FEHBP to the general public. The Act "Federal Employees Health Benefits Access Act" requires that carriers offer the same benefits to the general public as to employees and annuitants, with premiums set according to Office of Personnel Management regulations. The Act "Federal Employees Health Benefits Access Act" mandates that carriers must provide the same benefits to employees, annuitants, and their family members without increasing contributions or reducing benefits. Benefits under this section must be offered to individuals entitled to benefits under part A of title XVIII of the Social Security Act. Carriers can apply to be excluded from certain requirements of the Act by demonstrating reasons such as enrollment restrictions or financial solvency concerns. Carriers can request exclusion from Act requirements by demonstrating reasons like enrollment restrictions or financial solvency concerns. The duration of the exclusion and compliance efforts must be specified. Any reference to this chapter in law does not include this section. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 89 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 3. STANDARDIZED CLAIMS PROCESSING. A claim for payment or reimbursement under this chapter shall be submitted on a standard form as required by the Office for health benefit plans. Each contract under this chapter must include provisions for this process. SEC. 4. ADVANCE DIRECTIVES. SEC. 4. ADVANCE DIRECTIVES. The Office will provide information on advance directives for individuals unable to communicate due to illness or injury. Contract approval under section 8902 will require provisions for this information to be available to plan enrollees. The Office of Personnel Management will conduct a demonstration project to assess using arbitration instead of litigation for medical malpractice claims related to covered health care services under chapter 89 of title 5, United States Code. The project will be conducted under section 4703 of title 5, United States Code. The Office of Personnel Management will provide suggestions for incentives to encourage voluntary participation in health benefit plans, criteria for plan inclusion, arbitration framework details, and the impact of arbitration awards. The evaluation of the arbitration process under the demonstration project includes data on the number of claims, their resolution, average dollar amount of awards, costs, and the advantages and disadvantages of arbitration compared to other dispute resolution methods. The amendments made by this Act will apply to contract terms starting after a 6-month period from the enactment date.
